newsitem.title: USA: BEFORE THE BELL - Chips get lift from book-to-bill.
newsitem.headline: BEFORE THE BELL - Chips get lift from book-to-bill.

text.p: Shares in semiconductor and related technology stocks firmed ahead of Tuesday's market open on a stronger-than-expected monthly reading of demand for computer chips, traders said.
Intel Corp rose to 131-5/8 from 130-1/8, International Business Machines added 1/2 to 160-1/2, Applied Materials rose 5/8 to 40-3/8 and Microsoft traded at 83-1/8, up from 81-3/4.
Though not yet active, traders said they expected strength in Motorola Inc, Advanced Micro Devices and Texas Instruments.
Last night, the Semiconductor Industry Association said its book to bill ratio, which measures orders against shipments, rose to 1.15 in November from a revised 1.11 in October.
Industry analysts had expected the ratio to be flat to slightly higher versus October. The ratio means manufactures received $115 in new orders last month for every $100 in shipments.
Netscape Communications Corp added 1-1/4 to 61-1/4 on news of a marketing agreement with five regional bell companies.

Komag Inc, a supplier of thin-film media for computer hard disk drives, suffered from investors' exodus after it said last night fourth quarter earnings will be below expectations and under the prior quarter's $0.31 per share.
The stock was knocked down to 27-1/2 from 33-1/8 preceding Tuesday's market open.
Traders said Read-Rite, a maker of recording heads and other components for disk drives, fell in selling related to the Komag news, slipping one to 25-3/8.

Other stocks that were active before the bell were: Dell Computer, up one to 61-1/2, Comcast trading in line with the 17-3/4 prior close, American Power Conversion, up 1/4 to 27, Oracle at 49-5/8 up from 48-3/4, Cisco Systems, up 1-1/8 to 68-7/8, Sun Microsystems gained one to 60-3/4.
Also, there was a 150,000-share trade of Nordstrom Inc at 42-1/8, of 1/8 from Monday's close.
